Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d7ea283b7ec6c7718ac70b0d38c654b9a5bac3db

It's generally preferable for the commit message's subject line to describe the change made by the commit, rather than the problem it's addressing (https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/1e09b3cbdb223e2885bc6ba83e84a5cd5a728776/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages).
Done
I modified the commit message, along with adding the component name, but I didn't manage to be under 50 caracters.

It would be good to generalize the description a bit here -- it'd be fine to motivate by citing a specific platform and perhaps speculate a bit about the underlying reasons, but ideally the main focus of the commit message would be more generic (e.g. mentioning that NMI button presses aren't terribly interesting when the host is off, which is true even on hardware that doesn't generate bogus button-press events when it shuts down).
Done
Ok, I updated the description
Oh, and there should be a blank line separating the body from the tag lines at the end (Change-Id, Signed-off-by, etc.).
Done
Line added
Code looks fine to me; just a bit of commit message cleanup to do IMO...

Sorry to nitpick the commit message further, but in the context of the x86-power-control repo itself, putting the repo name as a subject-line tag is a bit redundant, so I'd suggest removing that part.
I saw the component in front of all other changes in gerrit, so I thought it was required. So now I'm in the 50 caracters, nice.

...though actually now looking at this further I'm wondering if maybe we should broaden the scope of what's skipped if the host is off -- i.e. maybe combine the powerState check into the `if (!state)` check with `&&`, or perhaps just put an `if (powerState != running) return` as the first line of the function?

Not sure...possibly Jason or Kuiying can chime in with any thoughts?

I agree. To me the logging still has some benefit when the host is off, but sending the NMI through to the host probably doesn't.  Unless the NMI source value in D-Bus should still be updated even when the host is off?

> but sending the NMI through to the host probably doesn't.

Does this code path have any control over that?  It doesn't appear to twiddling any GPIO outputs or anything, so it seems like the assumption is that the hardware is set up with that signal line run straight to the host and the BMC just gets to monitor it in a read-only fashion.

> Unless the NMI source value in D-Bus should still be updated even when the host is off?

I don't think I have any particular opinions on this at the moment; happy to go with whichever you prefer.

> Does this code path have any control over that?

Yes, it does, but it's convoluted:

On my hardware, NMI is a software-only button, meaning that the NMI button on the front panel is purely a BMC GPIO. It requires this code to detect the button press and call `setNmiSource()`.

From there, the `nmiSourcePropertyMonitor` will detect the PropertiesChanged event and call `nmiReset()`: https://github.com/openbmc/x86-power-control/blob/master/src/power_control.cpp#L2169.

`nmiReset()` will then twiddle the NMI GPIO output from the BMC to the system: https://github.com/openbmc/x86-power-control/blob/master/src/power_control.cpp#L2112.

So, in the current code, we suppress the NMI button log message, but continue with setting the source and pulsing the NMI output GPIO to the system (which I assume is ignored because the system is off).

Oh interesting, I hadn't realized there was all that going on there (the dbus indirection threw me off the path as I was tracing through it)...and yes, I think our hardware works the same way actually.  Thanks for the clarification.

I don't think I agree with this as a broad change.  It's true that NMI doesn't mean anything when the host is off, but the NMI button is user-facing, so it seems useful to know if users are messing with buttons regardless of the state of the host.

If hardware-specific patching isn't an option, perhaps this filter could be added as a build or configuration option?

> I mean it's an event that the BMC can detect and log, but if the host isn't powered on to respond to an NMI in any way, I guess I'm sort of unclear on what's interesting or useful about it -- in that state it just seems kinda like a dummy GPIO.

I think the clarification below that, at least on my system, the NMI button doesn't go directly to the system may help clarify my thoughts. Essentially, I look at the NMI button as nothing more than a dummy GPIO that users can control from the front panel.

I guess I'm cautious about BMC filtering events as I feel like we get into as much or more trouble for missing real events as for logging spurious ones.😊

I'm still mulling over what might be affected by filtering the NMI event when the host is off, but here are some of my other thoughts:
- If the event was "OK" severity, would that help? I see that both the Power and Reset button press events are "OK". I don't know why NMI was considered more critical than those, so it would make sense to me to reduce the severity of the button press to "OK".
- Instead of filtering just the logging on host-off, we could filter the entire event (setting the source, pulsing the output GPIO, etc.). Would that make the config option easier to write?  Maybe something like:
```
"event_configs": {
   "NMIWhenPoweredOff": false
}
```

> I think the clarification below that, at least on my system, the NMI button doesn't go directly to the system may help clarify my thoughts.

Yeah, with that cleared up I can see more why we might want to keep logging it.

> If the event was "OK" severity, would that help?

I think it'd certainly be an improvement, yeah (logging a spurious "OK" event is definitely better than logging a spurious "Critical" event), though not a complete fix for us (a spurious event is still a spurious event).  I guess an NMI does seem a bit more out of the ordinary than power or reset button events though...maybe a warning or something in between the two instead?

> Instead of filtering just the logging on host-off, we could filter the entire event (setting the source, pulsing the output GPIO, etc.).

So have the config option just make it ignore the NMI button entirely when the host is off?  I think that sounds reasonable, and would work fine for our situation.  @ofaurax, want to draft up a version taking that approach instead?

> I guess an NMI does seem a bit more out of the ordinary than power or reset button events though...maybe a warning or something in between the two instead?

We can discuss more in a Gerrit review on bmcweb if or when we submit it, and I don't really have a strong opinion, but I guess in my mind these are all just front panel buttons that a user could press at any time, so I don't see why one would need to be a different severity than another.

>  @ofaurax, want to draft up a version taking that approach instead?

Yes, sure. Don't hesitate to comment intermediate patchsets, as I'm quite new to gerrit/openbmc/power-control

These 2 lines don't induce any rewrite, error or warning with clang-format 14.0.0.
However,regarding the .clang-format file, they should, as they lack braces around the 2nd line.
Is this the same for you?

Hmm, yeah, not sure what's going on there, I would also have expected it to complain about that.  (Manually running clang-format locally I get the same result with both 14 and 15.)  clang-format often seems like a pretty mysterious and unpredictable beast to me I have to say...unless someone else knows what's going on here, I guess I'd just say fix it manually to make it consistent with the rest of the code?

For the record, there is this new option in future clang-format 15, InsertBraces, which does exactly that: https://reviews.llvm.org/D120217
In the meantime, I'll add them by hand, as suggested.
It's looking good. A couple more minor comments.
It would be good to also add this into the JSON config file with the default as an example.
I added it in the config file
Did you perhaps forget to `git add` that?  It doesn't appear to be in the current patchset.
It's the modification in `config/power-config-host0.json`
Whoops, my mistake -- didn't realize I had the gerrit display set back to a previous patchset.
We could even put this code just after the `set_property(...)` before the `if`
Do we even want to do the `set_property()` in that case?  I would have assumed not, though I don't know exactly what Jason intended here..
Good point.  If we're skipping everything, we should probably not notify anything else about the button-press either.
Ok, so I put the code at beginning of the fonction

nit: `auto` is preferred only when the type is clear from the context.  In this case, it appears to be a `bool` which is pretty clear, but then is there any reason to use `auto` instead of just `bool`?
`events` is not of type `bool`, it's `events.value(...)` which is.
Looks good to me.  I'll leave it at +1 to make sure others have a chance for any additional feedback.
Zev is the only other reviewer since this was opened, so that's good enough for me. 😊
